textDisplay:
Rock, Paper, Scissors
There is a commonly accepted theory about the success each of these play stocks styles has against the others. The general rule is similar to the game Rock, Paper, Scissors - each style has advantages over one, but disadvantages against the other. A famous cliché amongst stocks fans and writers is "styles make fights".

Rock = stone yourself, don't move,hodl

Paper = spread dollars average

Scissor = dumped

textDisplay:
I've had many great times at gamestop. Sadly, the business model they go for nowadays doesn't appeal to me as a customer.

I can remember one time I got the wrong game from a gamestop employee and it actually turned out to be much better than the one I shopped for so I just kept it.
One time I bought a gamecube from them for $30 and when I got home and was about to put a game in saw that someone had left Metroid Prime inside on accident. Awesome stroke of luck there.
One time I was returning a defective game and they only had one other copy in the store. So the store manager and I had a race to see who could find the game first in a huge bin of games.
Another time I was stopping by a local shop on the way to my friend's house for a play session. I had recently bought Mass Effect 1 and 2. Still had them in the bag with receipt. At checkout the employee questioned me about the bag and after seeing the two games were more expensive than the one I was buying at the time he offered the new game to me for free.
Using a buy 2 get 1 deal, he was able to return the games I had, resell them to me, and add the new game for free.

Great memories from gamestops little mistakes and some great employees at the stores. Sadly, these things just don't happen anymore. The stores don't really feel like game stores.
textOriginal:

One time I was returning a defective game and they only had one other copy in the store. So the store manager and I had a race to see who could find the game first in a huge bin of games.

textDisplay: Honestly I've stopped shopping at Gamestop. The last few times I tried to buy a new game there they didn't have any copies other than the ones that were preordered. Sure I was usually going in on the release day or day after but I'd think they would have a few for people who didn't preorder the game available as well. So I just went to Walmart and bought it for like $10 cheaper.
textOriginal: Honestly I've stopped shopping at Gamestop. The last few times I tried to buy a new game there they didn't have any copies other than the ones that were preordered. Sure I was usually going in on the release day or day after but I'd think they would have a few for people who didn't preorder the game available as well. So I just went to Walmart and bought it for like $10 cheaper.

textDisplay: For whatever reason GameStop holiday 2020 decided for us to remove all actual game cases on the floor, replace them with display cover art, and it did not matter if we had the stuff in stock or not because WE CAN GET THAT ORDERED FOR YOU! So, holiday 2020 was so stressful for employees and parents coming in trying to find gifts. Luckily that idea was quickly reverted, but sadly it was too late for the mess it caused.
textOriginal: For whatever reason GameStop holiday 2020 decided for us to remove all actual game cases on the floor, replace them with display cover art, and it did not matter if we had the stuff in stock or not because WE CAN GET THAT ORDERED FOR YOU! So, holiday 2020 was so stressful for employees and parents coming in trying to find gifts. Luckily that idea was quickly reverted, but sadly it was too late for the mess it caused.

textDisplay:
Some Machievellian gatekeeping going on right here.

It's a ridiculous over-simplication to say that the SEC should protect 'investors'. This statement can only hold meaning by virtue of the tacit insinuation that retail don't count, and that they are too stupid to understand the market. If the markets are being compromised by what appear to be 'irrational' movements, look at the massive whale who exposed themselves to literally infinite risk by shorting 140% of the float, not at the band of minnows who have finally had enough of these despicable poachers.

Lastly, don't try to pivot the argument and patronise people by saying that predatory naked short selling is a natural part of the market. Short selling in itself is a natural part of the markets. But the point at which an institution has to lean on vast sums of margin debt to keep their outsized short position viable is probably the point at which they should realise that they are the problem, not the people who kicked back when they tried to play god.

To anyone agreeing with this guy, ask yourself why isn't he out here talking about how disgraceful the Archegos issue was and advocating for changes in law for family offices and hedge funds. HINT: it's not to make the markets fairer.
textOriginal:
Some Machievellian gatekeeping going on right here. 

It's a ridiculous over-simplication to say that the SEC should protect 'investors'. This statement can only hold meaning by virtue of the tacit insinuation that retail don't count, and that they are too stupid to understand the market. If the markets are being compromised by what appear to be 'irrational' movements, look at the massive whale who exposed themselves to literally infinite risk by shorting 140% of the float, not at the band of minnows who have finally had enough of these despicable poachers.

Lastly, don't try to pivot the argument and patronise people by saying that predatory naked short selling is a natural part of the market. Short selling in itself is a natural part of the markets. But the point at which an institution has to lean on vast sums of margin debt to keep their outsized short position viable is probably the point at which they should realise that they are the problem, not the people who kicked back when they tried to play god.

To anyone agreeing with this guy, ask yourself why isn't he out here talking about how disgraceful the Archegos issue was and advocating for changes in law for family offices and hedge funds. HINT: it's not to make the markets fairer.

textDisplay:
If the SECs job is to protect investors then define investor.
Investors are in it for the long haul and would have stayed in on the stock.
Traders, however, are not investing. They are trading and gambling with leverage and shorts. These people are not investors and don't need protecting.
Therefore, the appearance of the SEC protecting the Traders was not protecting the investors at all.
It was a trading war between retail and institutions and that is a clear sign of which side the SEC is on.

I don't understand why we're giving credit to the "horde" of retail investors for the explosion of meme stocks. THEY ARE ALL MOVING IN UNISON (eg $AMC, $GME, $BB, $KOSS, $EXPR, $SNDL etc). Retail investors can't do that. Sure, they started this movement. But they can't move all of those meme stocks up 10% in a day AT THE SAME TIME.

It's pretty clear that it's algorithms from institutions causing this at this point. Again, reddit was the spark. But they're not moving these prices. It's a tug of war between institutional bears and bulls.

textDisplay: It's a socio-political trading environment focused on behavioral economics and game theory. GME/AMC are great stocks to be in because the CEO wouldn't be able to show his face on the planet if the price dropped out. It wouldn't make much sense for long to sell because retail has a history of buying every dip, therefore whales wouldn't be able to get back in quickly enough. Corporate leadership wants the price to continue upward, keep momentum going, and keep this massive following they have who have become loyal consumers/supporters. It's a new world of collective hive-mind trading. I like it. Once I saw those big red candles today, that's clearly manipulation, so pick your spot, buy some calls, wait for the rubberband to snap back.

textDisplay: The price of AMC was obviously being manipulated back in March. The day I went all in on AMC was when I saw over 150M shares trade between 13.98 and 13.99. Find me any other stock on the market that trades for an entire day on that volume within a penny spread. It doesn't exist. The day I saw that was the day I knew that some big institution with a high frequency trading algorithm stood to lose a whole SH_T TON of money if it broke 14. 2.5 months later it breaks 14 and now it's over 60. Coincidence? Swarm of retail traders driving the price up? Absolutely not. This security was heavily naked shorted, stacked with FTDs and now that the CEO called for a share recount someone is using the retail traders as an excuse to cover their naked shorts. It traded more than the entire float EVERY DAY this week. This is not volatility driven by retail traders IMO.

textDisplay:
You don't trade on fundamentals Dylan, it's straight up technical charting to identify the pushes. That's it. Identify structure/levels, intra-day trade off those level, exit and re-enter when next levels are hit and wait for confirmations.

Look left at structure, watch for pinbar/engulfing/whatever floats your boat type of signal, take the trade, repeat. Be correct 60% of the time and it's profit-city.
textOriginal:
You don't trade on fundamentals Dylan, it's straight up technical charting to identify the pushes.  That's it.  Identify structure/levels, intra-day trade off those level, exit and re-enter when next levels are hit and wait for confirmations.  

Look left at structure, watch for pinbar/engulfing/whatever floats your boat type of signal, take the trade, repeat.  Be correct 60% of the time and it's profit-city.

textDisplay:
AMC conviction

Dear fellow apes, For those of you not following the AMC story, I'll sum it up for you for context. CEO of amc Adam Aaron went on an interview with Trey Trades a Youtuber/ fellow ape last night. Some of the key takeaways are

1. ⁠⁠CEO stated they only have 46,000 shares left to dilute. Which means that the downward pressure by further diluting the shares is no longer happening.
2. ⁠⁠NONE of the 11.5 million shares diluted to raise capital for AMC went to any individual, including the CEO. He stated that originally, the money would go to high ranking employees to incentivize them, HOWEVER, he prioritized the company over filling his own pocket. NONE of it went to the employees. ALL cash raised from diluting those shares went to raising capital for AMC so that they can use it to recover from the pandemic.

*IMPORTANT PART: during the interview, Adam Aaron briefly adjusted his phone and during that brief moment, he faced the camera towards his legs notice he was NOT WEARING ANY PANTS. Ok lets back track for a bit. As a CEO of a company, he is NOT allowed to publicly state anything speculative. Why is this significant? Because he was asked about the synthetic shares being shorted. Since the share re count has not happened yet, he is not allowed to speculate on it. Now this brings us to the cryptic message when he "accidentally" showed us he is not wearing pants. This correlates with "Naked shorts" hence not wearing any pants. Coincidence? In my humble opinion, I dont think so. So to sum it up: Adam Aaron is sending us a cryptic message confirming that there are synthetic shares being shorted by showing that he is not wearing any pants during the interview aka "Naked Shorts". In addition, he is very active with the ape community on twitter so he knows how to communicate with us indirectly. Given this cryptic message is correct, it is stupid to NOT HODL your shares, since the hedgies over-leveraged themselves and illegally shorted shares that do not exist!! So in simple APE terms, the longer we HODL, the more the hedgies bleed, the higher price they're going to have to pay to buy back those shares since they simply did not exist. PLEASE do not listen to the media as they are working together with the hedgies to cause fear and doubt. We need to be unified and keep HODLING. This is a WAR and we have a clear shot at winning this AS LONG AS WE HODL.

We saw multiple millionaires being made from AMC the past week, but this is just the beginning! I wanna see more people paying off their MEDICAL BILLS, I wanna see more people paying off their STUDENT DEBT, I wanna see more people buying their FIRST HOUSE, I wanna see more people creating GENERATIONAL WEALTH. APE STRONG TOGETHER. I HODL FOR YOU, YOU HODL FOR ME 🖤♥️🖤

Oh and for the hedgies reading this: "I AINT FOOKN SELLIN 😤💎🙌🦍"

textDisplay:
But this is what is released on AMC website:
AMC Entertainment Holdings, Inc. Completes 11.550 Million Share At-The-Market Equity Offering Raising $587.4 Million in Additional Equity Capital
Company Release - 6/3/2021
LEAWOOD, Kan.-(BUSINESS WIRE)- AMC Entertainment Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: AMC) (“AMC” or “the Company”), announced that it has completed its 11.550 million share at-the-market (“ATM”) equity program launched earlier today. AMC raised approximately $587.4 million of new equity capital, before commissions and fees, at an average price of approximately $50.85 per share.

Commenting on the capital raise, AMC President and CEO Adam Aron said, “Bringing in an additional $587.4 million of new equity on top of the $658.5 million already raised this quarter results in a total equity raise in the second quarter of $1.246 billion, substantially strengthening and improving AMC’s balance sheet, providing valuable flexibility to respond to potential challenges and capitalize on attractive opportunities in the future.”
textOriginal:
But this is what is released on AMC website:

AMC raised approximately $587.4 million of new equity capital, before commissions and fees, at an average price of approximately $50.85 per share.

Commenting on the capital raise, AMC President and CEO Adam Aron said, “Bringing in an additional $587.4 million of new equity on top of the $658.5 million already raised this quarter results in a total equity raise in the second quarter of $1.246 billion, substantially strengthening and improving AMC’s balance sheet, providing valuable flexibility to respond to potential challenges and capitalize on attractive opportunities in the future.”

textDisplay: AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. AMC, -17.92% revealed Thursday afternoon that it will ask shareholders for the authority to issue up to 25 million shares, after selling stock into a dramatic upswell of its share price in recent days. "To successfully navigate the road ahead, we seek to assemble all of the financial tools that might help us," AMC Chief Executive Adam Aron said in a statement. "An important tool for any company is having shares available to issue if, and only if, the right value creation opportunity arises." AMC previously planned to ask shareholders for approval to issue up to 500 million fresh shares, roughly as many as are currently in circulation, but canceled those plans after an uproar from investors

In the Dot.com bubble there literally were TV adds for deutsche Telekom stock (I've heard, I was an infant back then). and more recently the wirecard scandal, another german favorite.  That's why once 8% of us are even in the equity markets in the first place

Meine Erfahrung habe ich zeitgleich gesammelt aber mit ungleichem Erfolg. Hatte aber tatsächlich nur wenig Geld über für so was. Hab Telekom, t-online, awd und Grenke gezeichnet und Gott sei Dank mit Stopps abgesichert, bevor die implosion losging. Und jetzt? Versuche ich mit meinem halbwissen, meine Kinder (5,8,9) die Börse zu erklären... Je früher desto besser....gibt es eine Liste von guten Büchern, die du empfehlen könntest.

textDisplay:
@Armin
Danke für den Content. Der Typ ist mutig. Das muss man ihm lassen. Wir alle wissen aber auch, dass man extrem große Vermögen nur mit einer Konzentration des Kapitals hinbekommt. Für mich selbst ist das nichts. Ich streue gerne mein Kapital sowohl in unterschiedliche Assets als auch innerhalb von Assets. Das ist für mich persönlich die bessere Variante. Ja, ich weiß, dass ich damit nicht ultrareich werden kann. Aber, ich kann gut schlafen und muss nicht jede Nacht zittrig ins Bett gehen. Alles in Bitcoin? Nein, auf keinen Fall. Dennoch bin ich von Bitcoin extrem überzeugt. Ich habe fast 1 Jahr gebraucht, um Bitcoin zu verstehen. Nie wieder würde ich auf Bitcoin als eine Assetklasse verzichten. Bin im April letzen Jahres eingestiegen und kaufe monatlich dazu. Völlig egal, was der Bitcoinpreis macht. Ich halte und verkaufe nie - vererbe ich später an die Kinder. Aber auch andere Assets sind gut z.B. Aktien, Kredite, Bargeld, Immobilien. Auch Edelmetalle und Rohstoffe sind keine schlechte Variante. Entscheidend ist für mich die Mischung und vor allem das Verhältnis. Eine gleichmäßige Aufteilung halte ich für nicht günstig. Die Aufteilung richtet sich bei mir nach dem Risiko - also die Frage, welchen Verlust kann ich verkraften, wenn ein Asset komplett scheitert und wie hoch ist die Wahrscheinlichkeit.

Innerhalb der Assets diversifiziere ich auch (egal, ob Immobilien, Krypto, Aktien oder Kredite). Wie sagt man so schön: Lege nicht alle Eier in einen Korb.

Dennoch: Ich finde es mutig von dem Typen. Wer viel will, muss halt viel tun. In diesem Fall bedeutet "viel" = hohe Risiken eingehen. Zockerei ist nichts für mich. Dann müsste ich auch Lotto spielen. Ich habe schon Glück in der Liebe.

textDisplay:
Ich bin Fan von einem gewissen Klumpenrisiko. Also in assets zu investieren, die dann einen Trend ausbilden und dann in den Anstieg die Position nach und nach ausbauen. Wichtig ist dann auch wieder nach und nach auszusteigen. Im Grunde das ausnutzen von Zyklen im Markt und entsprechend Positionen auf und wieder abzubauen. Beispiel vom April 20 bis heute: Wachstum bis Herbst
- - >Krypto bis März - - > Rohstoffe, Edelmetalle seitdem. Dabei kauft man nicht im Tief und verkauft nicht im Hoch, bekommt aber durch die Positiongröße die Gewinne. Klumpenrisiko ist immer auch eine Klumpenchance.

textDisplay: Ja ich hab es mit btc gemacht. Seit 2017 all mein geld und weitere Einkünfte da rein. Nur dass ich wirklich dran geglaubt habe hat mich den bärenmarkt 2018-2020 bei der Stange gehalten. Vor ein paar Monaten habe ich viel verkauft, weil meine Ziele erstmal erreicht wurden. Danach habe ich dann viel von dem Geld auf eine Aktie gesetzt aber schnell wieder verkauft, weil ich zu nervös wurde. Da hat sich genau das mit dem Glauben bemerkbar gemacht, bei btc hatte ich einfach die ganze Zeit viel mehr Zuversicht, nur das hat mich die schlechten Zeiten weiter halten lassen. Jetzt stehe ich da und finde gerade nichts, wo ich wieder so viel Zuversicht entwickeln kann

textDisplay:
Der Typ wird untergehen...ich wünsche ihm Glück, er wird es brauchen. Gibt bestimmt hundert Tausende die negative Erfahrungen mit einer ähnlichen Strategie gemacht haben. Die Frage ist nun, machen diese Menschen Ihre Geschichte dann auch öffentlich ? 🤷🏼‍♂️ Einen größeren Respekt würde diesen Menschen zustehen, weil sie ihr Ego zurückfahren, um andere zu warnen. Wenn ein Zock aufgeht und man sich dann hinstellt und sagt man macht es öffentlich um andere in seiner Altersklasse zu motivieren, ist das in meinen Augen eher gefährlich als inspirierend ! 😅🤷🏼‍♂️ Drücken wir Davud die Daumen 😉
Ich glaube die Geschichte hat keinen Teil zwei...und wenn doch so werden wir bei einem negativen Verlauf davon nichts mehr erfahren. ✌🏻

textDisplay: Saw one of the new figments move like it was a tiny gif. Pretty cool. If every new level is like a hub world, things will be very interesting. Makes me think a trained psychonaut knows how to properly compartmentalize their thoughts. Part of the reason I believe the mind you explore in the Tumbler Experiment after entering the vehicle Raz grew up in was actually Oleander's. So much of what's in there ends up being foreshadowing for later, which is weird if it's supposed to be Raz's mind when he hasn't seen any of that yet.

textDisplay: We know this isn’t about fundamentals, it’s about fighting the banks/Wall Street for their corruption that nobody does anything about. They picked a weak target, attempted to naked short it into the ground, got caught with their pants down, then all the entities that are supposed to protect investors just straight up didn’t. What do you think naked short selling does in regards to capital? They basically get choked to death by blocking them from capital and get to keep the money they created from basically counterfeiting shares and not pay taxes. Then you launder the money with cryptocurrency then rinse and repeat. The only reason this hasn’t taken off is because >50% buy orders are going through dark pools then selling on open exchange between funds to drive the price down. When it takes off and the market crashes because of “meme stocks” the systemic overleverage problem will be exposed. Archegos lost how much money, what if the biggest funds in the world were involved? Think about that. That’s basically what’s happening. 2008 never ended and the problems has only gotten worse. Protect your retirement accounts and check your emails to see messages warning of value decreasing. Don’t let these idiots do it again.

textDisplay:
Some Machievellian gatekeeping going on right here.

It's a ridiculous over-simplication to say that the SEC should protect 'investors'. This statement can only hold meaning by virtue of the tacit insinuation that retail don't count, and that they are too stupid to understand the market. If the markets are being compromised by what appear to be 'irrational' movements, look at the massive whale who exposed themselves to literally infinite risk by shorting 140% of the float, not at the band of minnows who have finally had enough of these despicable poachers.

Lastly, don't try to pivot the argument and patronise people by saying that predatory naked short selling is a natural part of the market. Short selling in itself is a natural part of the markets. But the point at which an institution has to lean on vast sums of margin debt to keep their outsized short position viable is probably the point at which they should realise that they are the problem, not the people who kicked back when they tried to play god.

To anyone agreeing with this guy, ask yourself why isn't he out here talking about how disgraceful the Archegos issue was and advocating for changes in law for family offices and hedge funds. HINT: it's not to make the markets fairer.
textOriginal:

It's a ridiculous over-simplication to say that the SEC should protect 'investors'. If the markets are being compromised by what appear to be 'irrational' movements, look at the massive whale who exposed themselves to literally infinite risk by shorting 140% of the float, not at the band of minnows who have finally had enough of these despicable poachers.

Lastly, don't try to pivot the argument and patronise people by saying that predatory naked short selling is a natural part of the market. Short selling in itself is a natural part of the markets. But the point at which an institution has to lean on vast sums of margin debt to keep their outsized short position viable is probably the point at which they should realise that they are the problem, not the people who kicked back when they tried to play god.

To anyone agreeing with this guy, ask yourself why isn't he out here talking about how disgraceful the Archegos issue was and advocating for changes in law for family offices and hedge funds. HINT: it's not to make the markets fairer.

textDisplay:
If the SECs job is to protect investors then define investor.
Investors are in it for the long haul and would have stayed in on the stock.
Traders, however, are not investing. They are trading and gambling with leverage and shorts. These people are not investors and don't need protecting.
Therefore, the appearance of the SEC protecting the Traders was not protecting the investors at all.
It was a trading war between retail and institutions and that is a clear sign of which side the SEC is on.

textDisplay:
Just in case you want to talk about the shareholder meeting, here is some key information to know;

1.) The shareholder meeting will last only 15 minutes at around 11:15AM EST on 6/9 (nice)

2.) They’ll mostly talk about preliminary voting results as well as overall company outlook/plans, and allow shareholders that have not yet voted to vote in-person.

3.) They will make an SEC-8K filing within 4 days after the meeting to announce and put on paper the official total voting results.
textOriginal:
Just in case you want to talk about the shareholder meeting, here is some key information to know;

1.) The shareholder meeting will last only 15 minutes at around 11:15AM EST on 6/9 (nice)

2.) They’ll mostly talk about preliminary voting results as well as overall company outlook/plans, and allow shareholders that have not yet voted to vote in-person.

3.) They will make an SEC-8K filing within 4 days after the meeting to announce and put on paper the official total voting results.

textDisplay:
AMC conviction

Dear fellow apes, For those of you not following the AMC story, I'll sum it up for you for context. CEO of amc Adam Aaron went on an interview with Trey Trades a Youtuber/ fellow ape last night. Some of the key takeaways are

1. ⁠⁠CEO stated they only have 46,000 shares left to dilute. Which means that the downward pressure by further diluting the shares is no longer happening.
2. ⁠⁠NONE of the 11.5 million shares diluted to raise capital for AMC went to any individual, including the CEO. He stated that originally, the money would go to high ranking employees to incentivize them, HOWEVER, he prioritized the company over filling his own pocket. NONE of it went to the employees. ALL cash raised from diluting those shares went to raising capital for AMC so that they can use it to recover from the pandemic.

*IMPORTANT PART: during the interview, Adam Aaron briefly adjusted his phone and during that brief moment, he faced the camera towards his legs notice he was NOT WEARING ANY PANTS. Ok lets back track for a bit. As a CEO of a company, he is NOT allowed to publicly state anything speculative. Why is this significant? Because he was asked about the synthetic shares being shorted. Since the share re count has not happened yet, he is not allowed to speculate on it. Now this brings us to the cryptic message when he "accidentally" showed us he is not wearing pants. This correlates with "Naked shorts" hence not wearing any pants. Coincidence? In my humble opinion, I dont think so. So to sum it up: Adam Aaron is sending us a cryptic message confirming that there are synthetic shares being shorted by showing that he is not wearing any pants during the interview aka "Naked Shorts". In addition, he is very active with the ape community on twitter so he knows how to communicate with us indirectly. Given this cryptic message is correct, it is stupid to NOT HODL your shares, since the hedgies over-leveraged themselves and illegally shorted shares that do not exist!! So in simple APE terms, the longer we HODL, the more the hedgies bleed, the higher price they're going to have to pay to buy back those shares since they simply did not exist. PLEASE do not listen to the media as they are working together with the hedgies to cause fear and doubt. We need to be unified and keep HODLING. This is a WAR and we have a clear shot at winning this AS LONG AS WE HODL.

We saw multiple millionaires being made from AMC the past week, but this is just the beginning! I wanna see more people paying off their MEDICAL BILLS, I wanna see more people paying off their STUDENT DEBT, I wanna see more people buying their FIRST HOUSE, I wanna see more people creating GENERATIONAL WEALTH. APE STRONG TOGETHER. I HODL FOR YOU, YOU HODL FOR ME 🖤♥️🖤

Oh and for the hedgies reading this: "I AINT FOOKN SELLIN 😤💎🙌🦍"

textDisplay:
But this is what is released on AMC website:
AMC Entertainment Holdings, Inc. Completes 11.550 Million Share At-The-Market Equity Offering Raising $587.4 Million in Additional Equity Capital
Company Release - 6/3/2021
LEAWOOD, Kan.-(BUSINESS WIRE)- AMC Entertainment Holdings, Inc. (NYSE: AMC) (“AMC” or “the Company”), announced that it has completed its 11.550 million share at-the-market (“ATM”) equity program launched earlier today. AMC raised approximately $587.4 million of new equity capital, before commissions and fees, at an average price of approximately $50.85 per share.

Commenting on the capital raise, AMC President and CEO Adam Aron said, “Bringing in an additional $587.4 million of new equity on top of the $658.5 million already raised this quarter results in a total equity raise in the second quarter of $1.246 billion, substantially strengthening and improving AMC’s balance sheet, providing valuable flexibility to respond to potential challenges and capitalize on attractive opportunities in the future.”

Commenting on the capital raise, AMC President and CEO Adam Aron said, “Bringing in an additional $587.4 million of new equity on top of the $658.5 million already raised this quarter results in a total equity raise in the second quarter of $1.246 billion, substantially strengthening and improving AMC’s balance sheet, providing valuable flexibility to respond to potential challenges and capitalize on attractive opportunities in the future.”

textDisplay: AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. AMC, -17.92% revealed Thursday afternoon that it will ask shareholders for the authority to issue up to 25 million shares, after selling stock into a dramatic upswell of its share price in recent days. "To successfully navigate the road ahead, we seek to assemble all of the financial tools that might help us," AMC Chief Executive Adam Aron said in a statement. "An important tool for any company is having shares available to issue if, and only if, the right value creation opportunity arises." AMC previously planned to ask shareholders for approval to issue up to 500 million fresh shares, roughly as many as are currently in circulation, but canceled those plans after an uproar from investors
